thread.title: Truth in advertising: Hypocrisy Field at Husky Stadium
thread.title_full: Truth in advertising: Hypocrisy Field at Husky Stadium | The Seattle Times

author: Ron Judd
title: Truth in advertising: Hypocrisy Field at Husky Stadium
text:
You could feel Puget Sound swelling with pride last week when a home-team company, Alaska Airlines, generously offered up $41 million over 10 years to have its name attached to the plastic grass at Husky Stadium.
It’s difficult to imagine a local charitable organization more deserving of this largesse than the poverty-stricken University of Washington Athletic Department, where assistant football coaches barely earn more than a lunchroom full of public school teachers these days.
But the record-setting naming-rights pact is even more generous given self-proclaimed underdog Alaska’s longstanding protestation — argued in court, for years, at undisclosed cost — that it’s too poor to pay an egregious, $15 minimum wage to poverty-level employees at Sea-Tac.
Either things have turned around awfully quickly, or that was some serious housecleaning that produced a cool 40 mil between the leather sofa cushions in the first-class lounge.
Most Read Stories State Supreme Court: Charter schools are unconstitutional Sorry about really messing up Bumbershoot for you kids Seahawks Cutdown Day live thread: Seahawks set initial 53-man roster Seahawks agree to deal with veteran RB Fred Jackson, waive Robert Turbin Green River killer moved to Colorado prison to end isolation More shady accounting:
Husky Athletic Director to Forklift Driver in Bowels of Husky Stadium: “Another $41 million in cash? Sheesh! I guess park it over there in the corner, next to the $20 or $30 million in TV money.”
Note to U-Dub Regents: Seriously, isn’t this the tipping point at which you consider channeling some of that endless athletic cash flow to ordinary, debt-amassing, student non-athletes?
And to Alaska: Failing the above, imagine the goodwill you might have created by diverting half that money to an all-new U-Dub partnership that includes a scholarship endowment for non-student-athlete children of employees or contractors. We’re guessing that many of your ground crews are immigrant families who truly could use the boost.
Speaking of Academia: So sad to see three instructors at Washington State University getting trashed for banning clearly “oppressive or hateful” terms , including in one case “male” and “female,” from Gender and Race Studies courses. Our advice: Head west, folks. Y’all will fit right in among the PC-obsessed Seattle left wing, which would stand and watch its own house burn to the ground rather than risk being perceived as flame-exclusionary.
Have Grudge, Will Travel: Walking psychological study/state legislator Pam Roach, R-WWE, a longtime South King County dweller, is establishing convenient residency in Sumner for a planned 2016 run for the Pierce County Council . You know where all this is heading: Sooner or later, she’ll be starting at middle linebacker for the Bellevue High School football team.
This Week’s Walla Walla Onion Headline: Local “strategy consultant” DJ Wilson, writing on Crosscut.com last week, listed all the reasons Gov. Jay Inslee, D-Lean Management, should run for president. (The best one: “In short, Inslee has the time.”) So nice to see comedy writing gaining a foothold in Seattle.
And Finally: Orthopedic surgeons worked overtime last week after all the swift, knee-jerk responses from local editorial writers urging a possible name change for Mount Rainier in the wake of President Obama’s renaming of Alaska’s Mount McKinley to Denali. Sorry, apples and oranges. The driving force behind the McKinley change — widespread, local usage of “Denali” — does not exist here, at least outside the Inferiority-Complex Committee in Tacoma. Unlike McKinley, Rainier has carved out its own place in the local lexicon and culture that wholly overshadows the person it was named for. Move along.
Ron Judd’s column appears each Sunday. Reach him at rjudd@seattletimes.com or 206-464-8280.
